posts.cooked: Hello, I am currently trying to implement code which would allow my shooter motors to remain at the same constant speed even after one cargo is shot out (shooting cargo momentarily decreases speed). If we’re being completely honest im just lost on where to begin or go towards. Like I got my feedforward and P gains from sysid (ks kv etc) but I see people setting their FF value to a single number, I thought it was ks, kv and ka? For reference Im using Falcon 500s, and I know that theres something called velocity control loop but the ctre documentation doesnt explain how to put it in code. Any help would be really appreciated.

Set kF value using TalonFX.config_kF(slot, value) , or by using TalonFXConfiguration .

kF is equivalent to kV , just with different units.

Some useful reading:

Feedforward for TalonFX PID Programming

Primer on Closed-loop: Talon SRX and Victor SPX supports a variety of closed-loop modes including position closed-loop, velocity closed-loop, Motion Profiling, and Motion Magic. Talon SRX additiona...

What is “System Identification?”: In Control Theory, system identification is the process of determining a mathematical model for the behavior of a system through statistical analysis of its inputs...

posts.name: what?
posts.cooked: If your having code issues I can’t really help you unless you post your code. but if what your trying to stop is your flywheel slowing down after shooting a ball PID won’t fix that, you would want to increase the inertia of your shooter with a steel/ brass flywheel

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked:
I know that theres something called velocity control loop but the ctre documentation doesnt explain how to put it in code.

Here’s what our flywheel velocity control looked like. The arbitrary feedforward parameter lets you calculate voltages with your SimpleMotorFeedforward from Sysid (otherwise, you would config a kF value which is analogous to kV). Just remember that CTRE uses weird native units, in this case for velocity control specifically encoder counts per 100ms ( units = RPM / 60 * 2048 / 10 ). image 1352×453 46.6 KB

image 1352×453 46.6 KB

image 1352×453 46.6 KB

Feedback( PID ) control on the flywheel is purely to help you recover to speed faster between shots. You can only increase P so much until causing oscillation, and even then you have a hard limit of recovery time based on the acceleration of your flywheel at 12 volts. This is why other teams put extra rotational mass on their flywheel, to reduce the drop in RPM between shots.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: I believe that should be a / 60 not a * 60, otherwise correct.

First of all thank you for the example, just a few things: In the code you sent and according to what you said earlier is your kFF value basically your kV value? And if you are setting the speed using rotations per minute how come you use radians per sec?

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
sethP:

slowing down after shooting a ball PID won’t fix that

A PIDF can help you recover more quickly that lost speed after a shoot. You can also use 2 large motors or a lighter flywheel.

sethP:

want to increase the inertia of your shooter with a steel/ brass flywheel

This slows the least but takes a while to spin up and also slower to recover the lost speed even though it loses less speed per shot. My team has tried heavy, medium, and light wheels and we tend toward using medium-light wheel with one Falcon 500 wit PIDF control.

There are many CD threads about PIDF and recent ones include It's too hard to tune a shooter's PID and How to use WPILIB's simplefeedforward to calculate a rpm value?

How to use WPILIB's simplefeedforward to calculate a rpm value?

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked: Yes, the kFF value is automatically multiplied with the setpoint and applied to the output as a feedforward. This happens onboard the Talon FX, versus calculated on the Rio with arbitrary feedforward. The example is just converting RPM → radians per second → native CTRE units per 100ms

Yea i can see that working out better for me, thank you for the help

So I’ve made some progress and finally got the shooter to actually move using ff/pid but the motor makes thumping noises… Its very possible that its oscillating but if thats the case what method do i use to tune the shooter pid?

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked:
Start with only the feedforward, 0 PID gains. Make sure the shooter gets very close to all your targets by logging your target and actual RPM to a plot on your dashboard (preferably Glass).

After that, you can start increasing (only) your P value to increase the recovery speed after shots (remember that CTRE has weird units and a kP of 1.0 would mean outputting max voltage when your velocity error is about 300 RPM). You want to get this value as high as you can without causing oscillation-- it should not ‘overshoot’ the target RPM or should do so very little.

Also of important note is the fact that sensor delay plays a huge role in the ‘instability’ of your feedback control. There’s a certain point where it is impossible to increase your P gain on something like a flywheel as the system responds on a similar timescale to the delay of measurements it gets. Here’s the CTRE documentation page for adjusting the Talon FX’s encoder filtering (delay) Bring Up: Talon FX/SRX Sensors — Phoenix documentation . For a flywheel, the sample period and window should almost be at their minimums.

link_counts.title: Bring Up: Talon FX/SRX Sensors — Phoenix documentation

posts.cooked: I have two motors: one for shooting the ball and the other to reduce backspin, when I zero out all pid values only the backspin motor runs while the main shooter motor doesnt turn on. But if i give any of the PID constants a value (like 0.0001) it will turn on, do you know why this could be the case?

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked: Do you have your code on github? I would assume you have feedforward on the backspin roller but not the main roller.

Yea here it is: https://github.com/rambots/Robot-2022.git (shooter-controller branch)

Quake:

I would assume you have feedforward on the backspin roller but not the main roller.

Thats what I thought too but I swear that everything I had for the backspin roller I also had for the main roller…

posts.name: Nolan
posts.cooked:
Two things:

You are calculating feedforward voltage based on your measured velocity, you want to use the target velocity (If the motor is at 0 rpm… it requires 0 volts to reach 0 rpm).

This MotorController class uses the wpilib PIDController . The previous advice about using CTRE units applies to their software library’s velocity control mode-- you don’t have to use those units if you are not using their library for closed loop. With that being said, I would recommend using the CTRE closed loop control because of the sensor delay and flywheel instability I mentioned earlier. The CTRE closed loop control runs directly on the motor controller and does not have any extra delay to its encoder, while a wpilib PIDController would have to read measurements from the CAN bus.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Good advice to the OP and I’ll add a couple of hints that others new to PIDF have gotten wrong.

Quake:

0 volts to reach 0 rpm

This is correct and applies essentially linearly to all volts:rpm but 0 is a special case, normally, especially if using the CTRE internal PIDF in velocity mode. If you want to stop the motors, then revert to the voltage mode (%VBus) and set the volts to 0. Don’t stay in velocity mode and set the velocity to 0. In velocity mode the PID controller keeps running and might not find 0 or not find it very quickly.

Quake:

recommend using the CTRE closed loop control

I agree for the reasons given. The motor controller calculates every 1ms and the WPILib in iterative robot normally calculates every 20ms. But either one works. The error I’ve seen is mixing methods and using parts of both. That doesn’t work! The implementations and units are vastly different. For example, don’t use the WPILib feed forward to feed into the CTRE controller; that’s not what the Talon is expecting.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

For example, don’t use the WPILib feed forward to feed into the CTRE controller; that’s not what the Talon is expecting.

You can do this just fine through the arbitrary feedforward parameter.
